search_result.title: MLB trade deadline: Juan Soto to Padres tops MLB deals, signings ...
search_result.text:
Juan Soto’s trade to the San Diego Padres was the top headline on MLB’s trade deadline day, but some other big names were dealt as contenders jockey for the stretch run.

Earlier in the day, the 23-year-old Soto was traded by Washington just three years after winning the World Series. The Nationals got MacKenzie Gore, Luke Voit and four prospects in exchange for the next 2½ years of Soto’s career.

Among a flurry of moves before clock struck 6 p.m. ET, the Atlanta Braves landed reliever Raisel Iglesias, the Blue Jays got two-time All-Star Whit Merrifield and the Phillies made a deal for starter Noah Syndergaard.

Catch up on everything that happened Tuesday:

Previously-unvaxxed Whit Merrifield going to the Blue Jays

The Royals sent utility man Whit Merrifield to the Blue Jays just minutes before Tuesday’s trade deadline, even though the two-time All-Star was unvaccinated against COVID-19 and had to miss Kansas City’s trip to Toronto last month.

Merrifield drew the ire of Royals fans when, prior to their trip to Toronto, he said: “Something happens and I happen to get on a team that has a chance to go play in Canada in the postseason, maybe that changes.”

Merrifield is making $7 million this season and is due $2.75 million next season along with a $4 million bonus for spending fewer than 110 days on the injured list in 2022. He has an $18 million mutual option for 2024 with a $500,000 buyout.

Toronto, which began Tuesday with a three-game lead over Tampa Bay for the AL’s top wild card, was missing outfielder George Springer in the lineup for the third time in the last four games against the Rays due to a right elbow injury.

– Associated Press

Phillies get old rival Noah Syndergaard

Philadelphia brought in a familiar face to strengthen its rotation, trading for Los Angeles Angels right-hander Noah Syndergaard. The Angels will get outfielder Mickey Moniak and prospect Jadiel Sanchez in the deal.

Syndergaard, who pitched for the Mets from 2015-2021, signed a one-year deal with Los Angeles in the offseason after declining New York's qualifying offer.

Moniak gets a fresh start with a new organization after he was selected by Philadelphia with the No. 1 overall pick in the 2016 amateur draft. The 24-year-old Moniak is a .129 hitter in 47 career games.

Earlier in the day, the Phillies also acquired outfielder Brandon Marsh (Angels) and reliever David Robertson (Cubs).

Philadelphia sent minor league pitcher Ben Brown to the Chicago Cubs for the 37-year-old Robertson, one of the top relievers on the market ahead of the trade deadline. The Phillies got Marsh from the Angels in exchange for catching prospect Logan O’Hoppe.

Philadelphia is fighting for one of three NL wild cards. It hasn’t made the postseason since 2011.

– Associated Press

Braves beef up bullpen with Raisel Iglesias

The defending champions made a deal to solidify the back end of their bullpen right before the buzzer, landing reliever Raisel Iglesias in a trade with the Angels. Los Angeles is getting lefty Tucker Davidson and righty Jesse Chavez in return.

The 32-year-old Iglesias received Cy Young votes last season and signed a four-year $58 million extension with the Angels this past offseason. His 3.17 FIP (4.04 ERA) suggest that he's been unlucky so far in 2022. Iglesias joins closer Kenley Jansen and lefty A.J. Minter in the late innings for the Braves, who dealt reliever Will Smith earlier in the week.

Other MLB trade deadline deals

Yankees, Cardinals swap Jordan Montgomery and Harrison Bader

Minutes before Tuesday’s 6 p.m. MLB trade deadline, the Yankees cleared roster space in an unanticipated manner.

Lefty starter Jordan Montgomery was shipped to the St. Louis Cardinals for center fielder Harrison Bader, who is currently on the injured list due to plantar fasciitis.

The left-handed Montgomery, 29, was having a solid season, posting a 3.69 ERA in 21 starts.

Bader, 28, a right-handed hitter, was batting .256 with a .673 OPS in 72 games, with 15 stolen bases in 17 attempts.

– Pete Caldera, NorthJersey.com

Eric Hosmer heading to Red Sox on roller-coaster day

Originally part of San Diego's package in the Juan Soto trade, veteran first baseman Eric Hosmer utilized his no-trade clause to nix a deal to Washington before the Padres ended up trading him to the Red Sox.

The Red Sox are sending pitching prospect Jay Groome to the Padres in exchange for Hosmer and prospects Corey Rosier and Max Ferguson. Hosmer is due $39 million from 2023-2025 and Boston will also receive cash in the deal

Padres get Brandon Drury in latest deal

San Diego followed up on the Soto trade by making a move for Reds utilityman Brandon Drury, who was enjoying a career year in Cincinnati with 20 HR and 59 RBI in 92 games.

The 29-year-old has played all four infield positions this year – primarily third base – and has experience in the outfield. Drury could get at-bats at designated hitter the Padres' new-look lineup with Soto and first baseman Josh Bell.

The Reds are getting 18-year-old shortstop prospect Victor Acosta, the Padres' sixth-ranked prospect (after the Soto trade) according to MLB.com.

Twins make move for Reds righty Tyler Mahle

With two of the best pitchers available on the trade market, the Cincinnati Reds opted to boost their farm system. The Reds traded right-handed starting pitcher Tyler Mahle to the Minnesota Twins for a group of three prospects Tuesday afternoon.

The prospects include infielder Spencer Steer, left-hander Steven Hajjar and third baseman Christian Encarnacion-Strand. Steer is the headliner, rated No. 4 in the Twins' organization by Baseball America. Hajjar is rated No. 11 and Encarnacion-Strand is ranked No. 14.

Mahle had a 5-7 record and a 4.40 ERA in 19 starts with the Reds this season, striking out 114 and walking 39 in 104 1/3 innings. He made two starts ahead of the trade deadline after a stint on the 15-day injured list with a right shoulder strain.

It’s the second time the Reds have traded a starting pitcher to the Twins this season. They swapped Sonny Gray for pitching prospect Chase Petty in March.

– Bobby Nightengale, Cincinnati Enquirer

David Robertson to close for Phillies

Seemingly always in the market for bullpen help, the Philadelphia Phillies struck a deal with the Chicago Cubs for closer David Robertson.

An All-Star in 2011 with the New York Yankees, Robertson made only 19 appearances from 2019-21 because of injuries. However, he's rebounded in a big way with the Cubs this year, posting a 2.23 ERA with 14 saves.

Class A right-hander Ben Brown, 22, goes to Chicago in the deal.

NL East contenders set to add outfielders

The Philadelphia Phillies have struck a deal to land outfielder Brandon Marsh from the Los Angeles Angels. In return, the Angels receive catching prospect Logan O'Hoppe, FanSided's Robert Murray reports.

Marsh, 24, is a speedy outfielder who can fill the Phillies need in center. However, he has the highest strikeout rate of any qualified hitter in the majors this season at 36.2%.

Meanwhile, the New York Mets are acquiring outfielder/first baseman Darin Ruf from the San Francisco Giants in exchange for veteran third baseman J.D. Davis and prospects, according to Joel Sherman of the New York Post.

Ruf, who has a .886 OPS vs. left-handers this season, gives the Mets a right-handed complement to lefty sluggers Dan Vogelbach and Tyler Naquin, who were also acquired just before the deadline.

Dodgers acquire OF Joey Gallo from Yankees

One of the surest bets of this year's trade deadline was that the New York Yankees would part ways with outfielder Joey Gallo, whom they acquired to much fanfare at last year's trade deadline.

However, in Gallo's one year in the Bronx, he has gone from an All-Star and Gold Glove defender to a struggling part-timer. In 140 games in pinstripes, he has produced a .159/.291/.368 slash line with 25 home runs and a whopping 194 strikeouts.

In a recent interview, Gallo was quite candid about his struggles, both physically and mentally, in New York.

Once the Yankees picked up left-handed hitting outfielder Andrew Benintendi from the Royals, Gallo's days were clearly numbered.

The Los Angeles Dodgers have agreed to send 23-year-old Class AA right-hander Clayton Beeter to the Yankees for Gallo, according to multiple media reports.

Beeter is the Dodgers' No. 15 prospect, according to MLB.com.

Blue Jays bolster bullpen in deal with Marlins

The Toronto Blue Jays added a pair of relievers for the stretch run, acquiring right-handers Anthony Bass and Zach Pop from the Miami Marlins for shortstop prospect Jordan Groshans.

Bass has been outstanding this season, with a 1.41 ERA, 0.94 WHIP and just one home run allowed over 44 ⅔ innings. Pop has split time between Miami and Class AAA Jacksonville. They'll provide depth behind closer Jason Romano.

Groshans, a top-100 overall prospect entering this season, has struggled at Class AAA Buffalo, posting a .250/.348/.296 slash line with one home run in 279 plate appearances.

Juan Soto trade to Padres now official

The San Diego Padres are making a huge statement in their bid to reach the World Series by landing the trade deadline's biggest prize, agreeing to acquire All-Star outfielder Juan Soto and first baseman Josh Bell from the Washington Nationals.

In return, the Nationals receive first baseman Luke Voit, left-hander MacKenzie Gore and a package of four prospects, shortstop C.J. Abrams, outfielders Robert Hassell III and James Wood, and right-hander Jarlin Susana.

ANALYSIS: Padres show they're all-in with Soto, Hader acquisitions

Veteran first baseman Eric Hosmer was originally part of the Nationals' haul for Soto and Bell -- however, he has a limited no-trade clause that prohibited him from being traded to several teams, including the Nationals, without his permission.

However, Voit was later added to the trade so it could be finalized.

Earlier this season, the Soto turned down a record-breaking 15-year, $440 million contract offer to stay with the Nationals. Even though the deal would have been the largest in baseball history, it would only average $29.33 million per year -- making him the 20th highest-paid player in annual value.

Twins pick up Orioles closer Jorge Lopez

Desperate for bullpen help, the Minnesota Twins have acquired 2022 AL All-Star Jorge Lopez from the Baltimore Orioles.

The O's will receive left-hander Cade Povich, right-handed reliever Yennier Cano and additional low-level prospects in exchange for the 29-year-old Lopez.

In by far the best season of his seven-year career, Lopez has made the transition from struggling starter (3-14, 6.07 ERA in 2021) to lights-out closer -- converting 19 of 23 save chances and pitching to an ERA of 1.68 in 44 appearances.

The Twins have gone through several closers after trading 2021 All-Star Taylor Rogers to the Padres this spring. Emilio Pagan leads the team with nine saves, but has blown six other save chances and has an ERA of 4.75. Five other Twins relievers have picked up at least one save.

Fantasy winners and losers (so far) from deadline deals

MLB teams aren't the only ones looking to improve their rosters at the trade deadline. In the upcoming issue of USA TODAY Sports Weekly, Steve Gardner offers his winners and losers from a fantasy standpoint. Here are a few of each:

WINNERS

SP Luis Castillo, Mariners. Somehow, Castillo managed to put up a 2.86 ERA and 1.07 WHIP with Cincinnati – in one of the most homer-happy ballparks in the majors. In Seattle, he’ll have a much more neutral home park and a better defense behind him. The schedule helps as well with the M's having 25 games left against sub-.500 division opponents the Angels, Rangers and A's -- and none against the first-place Astros.

RP Devin Williams, Brewers. MLB saves leader Josh Hader's fantasy value wasn’t going to change whether or not he changed teams. Once he did though, going from the Brewers to the Padres, Williams’ immediately becomes a top-10 fantasy closer in Milwaukee. Possibly top five. (The Orioles' Felix Bautista gets a similar boost in value with Jorge Lopez traded to Minnesota.)

1B Trey Mancini, Astros. Mancini was one of the hitters most impacted by the Orioles moving the left field wall back 30 feet this season. After hitting 14 homers at Camden Yards a year ago, Mancini had just five there this season (one of them of the inside-the-park variety). Hitting fly balls at a career-high rate, the Crawford Boxes in Houston, by comparison, should seem like just a short pop fly away for Mancini.

LOSERS

SP Frankie Montas, Yankees. With the Mariners landing Castillo first, the Yankees made a strong and successful push for the No. 2 starting pitcher on the market. Montas’ 4-9 record belies his excellent 3.18 ERA and 1.18 WHIP. However, he has taken full advantage of the spacious Oakland Coliseum this season. Over 12 starts in Oakland, Montas has a 2.06 ERA; in seven starts on the road, his ERA is over 5.00.

OF David Peralta, Rays. Primarily a platoon hitter, Peralta shouldn’t see much of a change in his role playing primarily against right-handers. However, the AL East is the toughest division in the majors and the Rays like to tweak their lineups more than most teams. The Rays also acquired outfielder Jose Siri on Monday and should have Manuel Margot and Harold Ramirez coming back off the injured list soon.

Fantasy managers in AL- and NL-only leagues. This could change with a flurry of activity on deadline day. But as the final 24 hours of trading began ticking down, the number of inter-division deals was disappointingly small. Perhaps the possibility of a Juan Soto trade has kept a number of other deals on hold. No matter the reason, hoarding one’s FAAB dollars until the last minute in hopes of grabbing a superstar from the opposite league seems to be yet again a dangerous gamble.

Padres front-runners in Soto sweepstakes?

The San Diego Padres are now seen by multiple observers as the "most motivated" team to put together a package for Juan Soto, in the words of The Athletic's Ken Rosenthal.

They have several high-level prospects -- including shortstop C.J. Abrams and outfielder Robert Hassell III -- which would be essential to creating a package the Nationals would accept.

Barry Svrluga of the Washington Post goes even further, calling the Padres the "most likely landing spot" for Soto. In addition, he says the Padres could also acquire first baseman Josh Bell as part of a Soto deal.

What makes the Padres different from the other rumored suitors for Soto is that they might have a bit more trouble getting him to sign a long-term extension before he becomes a free agent at the end of the 2024 season. That's because they already have two huge contracts already on the books in Fernando Tatis (14 years, $340 million) and Manny Machado (10 years, $340 million). However, Machado's contract does allow him to opt out after the 2024 season.

According to USA TODAY's Bob Nightengale, the Padres wouldn't necessarily have to deplete their farm system for years to come if they acquired Soto. They could always trade him for more top prospects before he becomes a free agent.

5 biggest trades from Monday

Yankees land Frankie Montas, have improved everywhere

The New York Yankees have been sitting atop the baseball world all season, but were much more worried about their team than they ever publicly revealed.

So, what did they do?

They grabbed Oakland A’s ace Frankie Montas on Monday when they couldn’t get Cincinnati Reds ace Luis Castillo. They passed on Brewers All-Star closer Josh Hader, who went to San Diego, but turned around and acquired Oakland closer Lou Trivino in the Montas trade. They acquired Cubs rookie reliever Scott Effross, too. They’re out on the Juan Soto sweepstakes, but acquired Andrew Benintendi from the Kansas City Royals last week.

– Bob Nightengale, USA TODAY Sports

Brewers think they can still win without Josh Hader

The Milwaukee Brewers let teams know early in July that four-time All-Star closer Josh Hader was available, believing they could still win the NL Central without him, but warned the asking price would be steep.

Well, they soon will find out if they’re correct in their assessment, trading Hader to the San Diego Padres on Monday for closer Trevor Rogers, starter Dinelson Lamet, pitching prospect Robert Gasser and outfield prospect Esteury Ruiz.

"Trading good players on good teams is difficult, and that certainly is the case with Josh," Brewers president David Stearns said. "We also recognize that to give our organization the best chance for sustained competitiveness, to avoid the extended down periods that so many organizations experience, we must make decisions that are not easy."

– Bob Nightengale, USA TODAY Sports

The 2022 Tigers weren't supposed to be sellers. How it all went wrong.

There was a time, not too long ago, when the Detroit Tigers envisioned a much different approach at the 2022 trade deadline — 6 p.m. Tuesday, less than two hours before they play the Twins in Minnesota.

On paper, the Tigers were lined up to compete. But on the field, due to myriad injuries and poor performances, the Tigers have the third-worst record in the AL, and the offense — averaging 3.21 runs per game — is one of the worst in baseball history.

"I'm just trying to make sure our guys realize we put ourselves in this situation," manager A.J. Hinch said. "We have to deal with the consequences of the stress, anxiousness, curiosity and the reality that, if I was on the outside and I had a contending club, I would have a few pieces that I would want here, too."

– Evan Petzold, Detroit Free Press

search_result.title: Snell: Dodgers-Padres NLDS at Petco Park should be 'insane'
search_result.text:
AP

SAN DIEGO (AP) — The atmosphere at Petco Park will be absolutely electric Friday night when Blake Snell and the San Diego Padres face Tony Gonsolin and the rival Los Angeles Dodgers in the first playoff game at the downtown ballpark with fans in the stands in 16 years.

The Padres put a jolt into the NL Division Series when they won 5-3 at Dodger Stadium on Wednesday night to even the best-of-5 series at 1-1. That assured them of two straight home games at the park that has been hopping pretty much every night during this season of big expectations.

“Yeah, I expect it to be pretty insane, which I’m really excited about,” Snell said Thursday before the Padres had a late-afternoon workout. “I really wanted to see what postseason baseball would be here in San Diego and at Petco.”

The only way the Padres assured themselves of getting at least one home game this postseason was to beat the New York Mets on the road in the wild-card round, which they did 2-1.

“I know when we beat New York, I saw the fans were going crazy, so I’m really excited to see what they’ve got, see what they bring, and hopefully we get a couple wins and can see them go even crazier,” Snell said. “I’m definitely really excited about it.”

If the Padres beat the Dodgers on Friday night in front of a sellout crowd, hometown hero Joe Musgrove will pitch the potential clinching Game 4 on Saturday night.

Snell has pitched in the playoffs at Petco Park before, making three starts with Tampa Bay in the AL bubble following the pandemic-shortened 2020 season, without fans in the stands. He faced the Dodgers twice in the World Series that year, including the ill-fated Game 6 when Rays manager Kevin Cash pulled him with the lead. The Rays lost the game and the series.

Snell moved on a few months later when he was traded to San Diego.

“This has always been one of my favorite ballparks to play in, so I cherish it a lot more being that now we’ll have fans and it’s San Diego fans and it’s in San Diego. I like that a lot more,” the left-hander said.

Snell, who won the 2018 AL Cy Young Award, has also moved on from that World Series start.

Asked what he remembered about that night, he said: “I knew that question was coming. That was inevitable. Yeah, it was one of my best starts. I’ll keep it at that. Two years ago, man. I’ve got to flip that page, read a different book, learn, get better.”

Wednesday night’s win was huge because the Dodgers have dominated the Padres going back to mid-2021, including going 14-5 this year and outscoring San Diego 109-47. The 111-win Dodgers won the NL West, finishing 22 games ahead of the Padres and earning home-field advantage through the World Series.

“It’s a different team,” Snell said about this year’s Dodgers lineup. “They’ve got Freddie Freeman, they’ve got Trea (Turner). It’s just a whole different team than two years ago. They’re a lot better, I think. They’ve gotten pieces that have made them a lot stronger hitting-wise.”

The Padres were carried offensively all year by All-Star Manny Machado. They finished 89-73 without superstar shortstop Fernando Tatis Jr., who was on the cusp of returning from a broken wrist when he was suspended 80 games by MLB on Aug. 12 after testing positive for a performance-enhancing drug.

The Padres won a home wild-card series against St. Louis in 2020, minus fans. The last time the Padres played in front of a packed Petco Park in the playoffs was 2006, when they lost both home games in the NLDS before the Cardinals finished off a 3-1 series win in St. Louis.

San Diego’s leadoff batter and left fielder that year was Dave Roberts, who’s in his seventh season helming the Dodgers.

The Dodgers have won nine straight series against the Padres. San Diego hasn’t won a playoff series in a full season since the 1998 NL Championship Series against the Atlanta Braves.

Snell can have a hand in changing that.

“There’s no better time to be great than right now,” said Snell, who was 8-10 with a 3.38 ERA in an up-and-down regular season.

Gonsolin, an All-Star who went 16-1 with a 2.14 ERA in the regular season, opposed Snell in Game 6 of the World Series two years ago. He’s not concerned about a loud crowd.

“Yeah, we’re fortunate enough to play here at Dodger Stadium, and we get 45-, 50,000 people every night when we play,” Gonsolin said during a video conference with the media. “Can’t imagine it’s any more loud than that. Yeah, I’m excited to go out there and throw strikes.”

Roberts said Gonsolin should be good for 75 pitches and that Dustin May and Andrew Heaney could follow him. Gonsolin was sidelined for much of the final 1 ½ months with a strained right forearm. He returned on Oct. 3, pitching two innings.

___

search_result.title: First look: Keys to winning the AL pennant
search_result.text:
USA TODAY Sports

With baseball’s spring training in full throttle, USA TODAY Sports examines the four keys to winning the American League pennant for each team. A look at the AL, in alphabetical order:

***

Baltimore Orioles

1. Solid corners: The tandem of first baseman Chris Davis and third baseman Manny Machado packs a punch. The Orioles re-signed Davis to the largest contract in franchise history, locking up their cleanup hitter at $161 million over seven years. He led the majors with 47 home runs last season and has 159 over the last four seasons. Machado, 23, is maturing into a perennial All-Star. He played every game last season, and his plate discipline has improved greatly.

2. Improved rotation? The late addition of Yovani Gallardo filled a gap. In 2015, no starter won more than 12 games, and the four returning (right-handers Chris Tillman, Kevin Gausman, Ubaldo Jimenez and Miguel Gonzalez) combined to go 36-40 and relied heavily on the bullpen. Gallardo, 30, has logged at least 180-plus innings in each of his last six seasons and could become the staff ace. Manager Buck Showalter expects a breakout season from Gausman.

3. Gold Gloves: The Orioles have some of the most sure-handed gloves up the middle of the field with catcher Matt Wieters, shortstop J.J. Hardy and center fielder Adam Jones. Each is healthy and has won multiple Gold Gloves. Last season, the O’s had the fewest errors in the American League. And with two-time Gold Glove winner Machado at third and Korean Hyun Soo Kim playing in left field, the Orioles expect to field a better defensive team.

4. Foreign import: Kim, 27, is coming off stellar 2015 campaign in the Korea Baseball Organization in which he hit a career-high 28 home runs. He should provide stability in left and at leadoff. Kim brings a much-needed left-handed bat to the lineup and has a high on-base percentage.

Scott Boeck

***

AL grades: Which team had the best offseason?

Boston Red Sox

1. Bounce-backs by Ramirez and Sandoval: Signed for a combined $173 million in free agency during the 2014 offseason, neither Hanley Ramirez nor Pablo Sandoval produced as expected last year. That was a major reason why the Red Sox finished last in the AL East for the second year in a row and third time in four years with a 78-84 record. GM Ben Cherrington was replaced as head of baseball operations by Dave Dombrowski. Ramirez will try to make the conversion to first base after struggling moving to left field from third base last season. Weight issues have dogged Sandoval throughout his career, and he might be heavier this spring.

2. Price living up to his price: Dombrowski made a big strike by signing free agent LHP David Price to a seven-year, $217 million deal in December. Price gives Boston the No. 1 starter it has lacked since trading Jon Lester during the 2014 season. Last season, Price helped the Toronto Blue Jays win the AL East crown, led the league in ERA and finished second in Cy Young Award voting.

3. Fine farewell by Big Papi: DH David Ortiz announced on Nov. 18, his 40th birthday, he would retire after this season. He has at least 30 homers and 100 RBI in each of the last three seasons while posting an outstanding .913 on-base-plus-slugging percentage in that span. Injuries are a concern, but Ortiz played in 146 games in 2015, his most since 2011.

4. Continued Kimbrel excellence: The Red Sox traded four prospects to the San Diego Padres for closer Craig Kimbrel. They look for Kimbrel to continue his elite performance in the AL after compiling 244 saves and a 1.63 ERA in 225 games with the Atlanta Braves and the Padres in his first six seasons.

John Perrotto

Boston's ambassador David Ortiz 'ready to pass the torch'

***

Chicago White Sox

1. In Todd we trust: The White Sox were last in the American League in 2015 in runs, home runs and slugging percentage, leading general manager Rick Hahn to trade for Todd Frazier. The veteran third baseman was fourth in the NL with 35 home runs for the Cincinnati Reds, so problem solved, right? The White Sox need Frazier to take control of the cleanup spot and provide better protection for Jose Abreu.

2. Straight A’s: Adam LaRoche and Avisail Garcia don’t need to be stars but do need to be better than last season. LaRoche, with a .634 on-base-plus-slugging percentage in 484 plate appearances, gets another chance, but that’s because he’s making $13 million and the White Sox could not trade him or find a suitable replacement. LaRoche, 36, has a track record of success, unlike Garcia. He’s 24, and although he was a highly regarded prospect with the Detroit Tigers, Garcia has never put together a full season to justify those expectations. He was underwhelming last season. Garcia says he has changed his swing, but he’ll have to turn that into more production to repeat last year’s 600 plate appearances.

3. Rounding out rotation: Left-handers Chris Sale, Jose Quintana and Carlos Rodon could be one of the top starting trios in baseball. But what follows them is less certain. Six years ago, John Danks and Mat Latos were among the game’s most dynamic pitchers. They’ll need to recapture some of that success.

4. High five: The White Sox have been rebuilding the last few years, so manager Robin Ventura has avoided the hot seat. Not so in 2016. Entering his fifth season leading the White Sox, he has a team that many — on the South Side and elsewhere — expect to contend in the AL.

Peter Barzilai

White Sox counting on Todd Frazier, Brett Lawrie to kick-start offense

***

Cleveland Indians

1. Lindor avoids sophomore slump: SS Francisco Lindor did not post eye-popping stats at Class AAA Columbus last season, hitting .284 with two home runs and a .752 on-base-plus-slugging percentage in 59 games. Yet the Indians thought he was ready when they promoted him June 14 and he proved them right by finishing second in the AL rookie of the year voting. Lindor, 22, also stabilized the defense while playing with a sense of confidence that belies his age. The Indians hope to contend in the AL Central after going 81-80 last season, and Lindor’s continued improvement would go a long way toward keeping them in the race.

2. Starting rotation dominates: Corey Kluber, who won the AL Cy Young Award in 2014, leads a rotation filled with power arms and includes fellow right-handers Carlos Carrasco, Danny Salazar and Trevor Bauer. All four have the stuff to dominate in any given start. The Indians got plenty of trade offers in the offseason but refused them all as they think the rotation is the backbone of the team and gives them the best chance to win.

3. Smooth recovery for Dr. Smooth: Left fielder Michael Brantley will begin the season on the disabled list as he recovers from surgery on his left shoulder in November. The Indians don’t expect Brantley to be ready until at least May 1. Veteran Rajai Davis was signed to a one-year, $5.25million free agent contract to be the fill-in.

4. Some pop from Napoli: Mike Napoli was signed to a one-year, $7million contract as a free agent to help provide punch to a lineup that was 18th in the majors in runs scored (4.16). He also should upgrade the defense by allowing Carlos Santana to become a full-time designated hitter.

John Perrotto

***

Detroit Tigers

1. Step forward for Norris: No, the Tigers aren’t expecting Daniel Norris to replace David Price, at least from the standpoint of innings pitched, strikeouts and the polish one expects from a Cy Young Award winner. But it’s crucial that Norris, the centerpiece of the package Detroit received for Price at the July trade deadline, hold down a spot in the middle of the rotation. Norris, 22, had a whirlwind year, starting in the Toronto Blue Jays rotation, getting sent down April 30 and then traded to the Tigers three months later. All while knowing offseason treatment for thyroid cancer was imminent. But Norris pitched well in eight starts with the Tigers. It should be all systems go this season.

2. Designated health: Signing Justin Upton gives Detroit a scary lineup — and a very right-handed one. The exception in the middle of the order: switch-hitting DH Victor Martinez. Entering the second season of a four-year, $68 million contract, Martinez is coming off an injury-plagued season in which his on-base-plus-slugging percentage dropped from a league-best .974 to a career-worst .667. At 37, a season somewhere in between would go a long way toward balancing the Tigers lineup.

3. New bully: After years of malfunctions, a revamped bullpen must be as good as it looks on paper. The key: New closer Francisco Rodriguez defying time and again posting a walks and hits per innings pitched near the 0.93 mark he produced over two seasons with the Milwaukee Brewers.

4. Big brain on Brad: Managers grow with time. In Year 3, we should get a good idea of Brad Ausmus’ ceiling. Improved in-game acumen might make a difference in what should be a hard-fought division.

Gabe Lacques

***

Houston Astros

1. Singleton stepping up: The Astros signed first baseman Jon Singleton to a five-year, $10 million contract in 2014, but he has hit .171 with 14 home runs and a .621 on-base-plus-slugging percentage in 114 games. The 24-year-old is being counted on to blossom this year, as a path to a starting job was cleared when Chris Carter, who hit 90 homers over three seasons with Houston, was not tendered a contract. The Astros are counting on Singleton to help them get back to the playoffs after they made their first postseason appearance since 2005.

2. Giles closing it out: Finding a hard-throwing reliever became a priority after the Astros blew a late three-run lead in Game 4 of the division series vs. the Kansas City Royals in October and wound up losing the series in five games. So the Astros shipped five players to the Philadelphia Phillies in a December trade for right-hander Ken Giles, and they think the 25-year-old can become a premier closer. Giles makes the bullpen deeper, as Luke Gregerson, last season’s closer, will move back into a setup role with Will Harris and Tony Sipp, who was re-signed to a three-year, $18 million deal.

3. An encore by Keuchel: Lefty Dallas Keuchel won the AL Cy Young Award last season while blossoming into an ace. In additional to being a 20-game winner, he went 15-0 at home at hitter-friendly Minute Maid Park and won his second consecutive Gold Glove, topping American League pitchers with 53 assists.

4. An encore by Correa: Carlos Correa, 21, the first overall pick in the 2012 draft, made his big-league debut June 8. Despite playing in 99 games, he led all shortstops in homers and was the first Astros player to be rookie of the year since Jeff Bagwell in 1991.

John Perrotto

***

Kansas City Royals

1. Keep the line moving: Their 2015 mantra also works as a bigger-picture rallying cry — carry over the cohesion, timely hitting and excellent defense that were hallmarks of the Royals’ consecutive runs to the World Series. After winning it all and bidding farewell to a few key parts, it’s incumbent on the core of All-Stars Eric Hosmer, Mike Moustakas, Lorenzo Cain, World Series MVP Salvador Perez, Alex Gordon and Alcides Escobar to maintain good health and productivity.

2. Eiland fever: Pitching coach Dave Eiland has received his share of credit for turning hurlers Jeremy Guthrie and Ryan Madson into viable contributors. In 2016, there’s no obvious reclamation project, but Ian Kennedy might prove an interesting pupil. The right-hander received a five-year, $70 million contract, even though he gave up 31 home runs and posted a 4.28 ERA for the San Diego Padres. If Eiland can smooth the rough edges, the rotation could be deep.

3. The right combo: Speed and defense are the Royals’ calling card, and they should get both out of the right-field platoon of Jarrod Dyson and Paulo Orlando. But will the duo hit enough? Orlando had a .269 on-base percentage in 251 plate appearances last year. Dyson, 31, has a lifetime .320 OBP. Will they benefit or be exposed by greater exposure?

4. Good vibrations: The brotherhood that has developed on this mostly homegrown squad is striking. But the kids — and their salaries — are growing up. The club might renegotiate Perez’s now famously below-market contract. Other core members are locked into two-year deals, with most hitting the market after 2017. Will the closing window spark urgency or create distractions?

Gabe Lacques

Royals� Salvador Perez's mom carjacked days before extension

***

Los Angeles Angels

1. Find the right rotation mix: Garrett Richards and Jered Weaver are locks for the rotation, and the same goes for C.J. Wilson if he avoids any setbacks in returning from left shoulder surgery. That leaves Andrew Heaney, Hector Santiago, Matt Shoemaker, Tyler Skaggs and Nick Tropeano for the final two spots. Heaney is a favorite for the No. 4 slot after a strong finish to 2015. Santiago struggled in the second half but should be the No. 5 with a decent spring training. Skaggs is returning from Tommy John elbow surgery, and Shoemaker and Tropeano are depth arms.

2. Get Albert Pujols healthy:After offseason foot surgery, the 36-year-old says he expects to be ready for opening day. That might be optimistic. The Angels need him to contribute. Although he hit 40 home runs last year, Pujols had the lowest batting average and on-base percentage of his career. With six years and $165 million left on his contract, the deal could go from bad to worse quick if he is slow to return to full strength.

3. Speaking of the lineup:

C.J. Cron looked primed for a breakout in 2015 but struggled early and was sent to the minors. He eventually came around but was never a consistent force. He enters spring training with the expectation that he’ll bat fifth or sixth and perhaps start the season at first base if Pujols is not ready or needs to DH.

4. And finally the rest of the lineup: The Angels need a lot to go right with their lineup after Mike Trout and Kole Calhoun. Newcomers Yunel Escobar, Andrelton Simmons, Daniel Nava and Craig Gentry are not impact players at the plate, but they’ll need to get on base and keep the lineup rolling over to ensure the Angels score enough runs this season.

Peter Barzilai

***

Minnesota Twins

1. Sano knowing right field: Miguel Sano made such a big impact last season after being called up from Class AA Chattanooga (Tenn.) and making his big-league debut July 2 that he was named the Twins’ MVP. Though a third baseman in the minors, Sano will be asked to play right field after South Korean slugger Byung Ho Park was signed as a free agent in the offseason. The Twins think Sano, 22, is athletic enough to be adept in right field despite being 6-4 and 260 pounds. The bigger question, though, is whether Sano’s defense will affect his hitting, because he has a chance to be a superstar.

2. Continued rotation improvement: Twins starters had a 4.14 ERA last season, which ranked 16th in the majors, and helped Minnesota go 83-79 following four consecutive seasons with at least 92 losses. The Twins were last in starters’ ERA in 2012 and 2013. If the rotation, led by RHs Ervin Santana, Phil Hughes and Kyle Gibson, takes another step forward this season, the Twins could earn their first postseason berth since 2010.

3. A healthy Perkins: Closer Glen Perkins is a three-time All-Star, but he is a question mark after being limited to 11 games, four saves and a 7.32 ERA in the second half of last season while bothered by neck and back pain. RHs Kevin Jepsen and Trevor May throw hard and should provide a strong bridge from the starters, but neither is a sure thing if needed to close.

4. A Buxton breakout: CF Byron Buxton was the consensus pick as baseball’s top prospect entering last season. But he struggled in a 46-game trial and was sidelined for 21/2 months by a sprained left thumb. But he is 22, and the Twins think he can spark a potentially explosive offense from the leadoff spot.

John Perrotto

***

New York Yankees

1. Sustained veteran success: This is not a young team. Seven of their nine starting position players are over 30. This is a team, however, made up of veterans who are still able to produce at a high level. Alex Rodriguez, 40, had a resurgent year, hitting his most home runs since 2008. Chase Headley, 31, bounced back with 150 hits. Brian McCann, 32, tied a career high in RBI last year. The Yankees have a few key young pieces, but this lineup is made up of aging stars.

2. Masahiro Tanaka’s durability: The Yankees’ $150 million man hasn’t been completely forthright about his injuries since arriving in 2014. He has missed time the last two years and required offseason surgery for a bone spur in his elbow that team officials didn’t know about until the October procedure. Tanaka is their ace, and when healthy he’s nearly lights out. The Yankees need to keep Tanaka healthy for a full season.

3. Get past division contenders: Last year the Yankees were 38-38 against their division rivals. Perhaps more worrisome is that they were 15-23 against the Blue Jays (first place) and the Orioles (third place). The Jays are going to have the best lineup in the league this season, the Red Sox added pitching and will be contenders again and the Orioles will bring back most of their 2015 squad. The East will be the AL’s toughest division.

4. Betances and Miller: New closer Aroldis Chapman has been suspended for the first 30 games stemming from a domestic violence incident. He chose not to appeal the ruling and won’t be eligible to return until May 9. The Yankees will turn again in the first month to Andrew Miller, who had 36 saves last season. Dellin Betances, as dominant as Miller last season, could fill in, too.

Michael Stern

In Aroldis Chapman case, MLB acted decisively, even without all the answers

***

Oakland Athletics

1. The rotation: Sonny Gray is the locked-in No. 1 guy for the A’s, but after him there are a bunch of injury risks. Jesse Hahn had elbow and forearm problems last season but should be healthy. Kendall Graveman is coming off an oblique injury that shut him down in August. Rich Hill will be 36 when the season starts and has been mostly a reliever but will get a shot at a starting job. Chris Bassitt missed time with a shoulder injury. There are lots of question marks and health concerns.

2. Efficiency at the top: Jed Lowrie is slotted to fill the second spot in the batting order behind Billy Burns. Neither Lowrie nor Burns will hit for power, but they get on base and don’t strike out. The centerpiece of any Billy Beane team is efficiency and on-base percentage, and Lowrie and Burns will make contact and get on base. With them starting off the order efficiently, it should set things up nicely for Josh Reddick.

3. Doolittle’s health: Closer Sean Doolittle was an All-Star in 2014 but in 2015 had two trips to the disabled list with shoulder injuries. Without Doolittle, Oakland had 25 blown saves, about half of their opportunities. The A’s brought in Ryan Madson as insurance, but Doolittle needs to return to his 2014 form (89 strikeouts in 62 2/3 innings) to ensure that their save percentage improves from last season’s 52%.

4. Overachieve: The A’s have made a living taking average and slightly above-average players and getting to the playoffs. This year is no different. Oakland’s farm system has a few key pieces, but they are a year or two away. This year the A’s need to do what they’ve always done. Gray, the only true star, is surrounded by role players who need to peak to put the A’s in contention.

Michael Stern

***

Seattle Mariners

1. Veterans must produce: Seattle has the third-oldest team in baseball, and its stars are some of the older players on the squad. This season, the Mariners’ success depends on the heart of the order: Robinson Cano, 33; Nelson Cruz, 35; and Adam Lind, 32. If the three sluggers can find their form, Seattle could be in decent shape.

2. Late-game lock down: Seattle blew 26 saves last season, and its bullpen went 21-36. It had the sixth-worst ERA in the majors at 4.15 and opponents hit .258. The situation wasn’t looking great, so the front office focused on the bullpen this offseason. The projected closer is newcomer Steve Cishek, who is a huge question mark. In seven opportunities early last season for the Miami Marlins, he blew four saves. His strikeouts were way down. He must return to form to lock down the ninth, which Seattle struggled with in 2015.

3. Back up King Felix: Felix Hernandez is the ace of this rotation, but he needs backup. That could come from Taijuan Walker. In his first full season in the majors he went 11-8, finishing strong. After a rocky start Walker went 9-2 holding opponents to a .241 batting average. Newcomer Wade Miley could make an impact. The five-year starter has made a living off of eating innings, pitching more than 190 in each of the last four seasons. But he will have to find his control. His strikeouts were down, and he has averaged about three walks per nine innings in his career.

4. Cruz’s health: Cruz is coming off two of his best years of his career, but has always been injury-prone. He has stayed on the field recently which has led to two years in a row with more than 40 homers, but in 10 years he has started 150 games only three times. He has to stay healthy.

Michael Stern

***

Tampa Bay Rays

1. Matt Moore’s strong return: Last season Moore struggled in his return from Tommy John elbow surgery before being demoted. Before his demotion, Moore went 1-3 with an 8.78 ERA, and batters hit .372 against him. He spent time at Class AAA Durham (N.C.) where he was able to get his strikeout stuff back, striking out 12.9 hitters per nine innings. When he came back in his final six starts, he held opponents to a .237 average and struck out 29 in 36 1/3 innings. The Rays will need to rely on their pitching, and Moore’s strong return is crucial.

2. Lock down the ninth: After being selected to his first All-Star Game, Brad Boxberger had a rocky second half, going 0-5, blowing four saves and posting a 4.33 ERA. He struggled with control, walking 32 in 63 innings and threw five wild pitches. Boxberger needs to prove he was the pitcher of 2014 (14.5 strikeouts and 4.7 hits allowed per nine innings) if the Rays want to win.

3. Get runners home: The Rays generated the sixth-fewest runs in the majors in 2015 despite having an average number of hits and batting average. Rays starters received the second-lowest run support in the majors. Tampa Bay was able to get runners on, but they were unable to get them in. There’s no question this lineup is the weakness of the Rays, and pitching will not be able to carry them if they get no run support.

4. Production from the catcher: Curt Casali will get the first shot at the starting job, but Rene Rivera and Hank Conger are waiting in the wings. None have shown promise with a bat. Rivera got a shot last year starting 87 games, but he hit .178 while striking out 86 times. Conger hit .229 with the Houston Astros. Casali hit 10 homers in 38 games in 2015.

Michael Stern



***

Texas Rangers

1. Desmond finding a home: After a long and frustrating winter, free agent Ian Desmond finally found a home, days after the club’s first-full workout. The twist? The former All-Star shortstop will move to the outfield. After Josh Hamilton’s knee injury, Desmond will play left field while Hamilton recovers. Desmond, who played his entire seven-year career at shortstop, has started one of his 927 career games in the outfield. “As far as swallowing my pride and moving to the outfield, that’s not going to be a problem,” he said.

2. Darvish returning: The Rangers expect Yu Darvish to return from Tommy John elbow surgery around mid-May or early June. He has shown great progress in his first workouts, and the Rangers think he will return to All-Star form. The right-hander, who has 680 strikeouts in 83 starts, last started a game Aug.9, 2014.

3. Staying healthy: For the second consecutive season, the Rangers were hit with the injury bug. They lost more than 1,400 games to the disabled list in 2015 — the most of any club. There were 26 different disabled list stints that included several key players including Darvish, Derek Holland, Adrian Beltre and Delino DeShields, yet the Rangers managed to win the AL West. The return of Darvish and Holland should give the rotation a huge lift — especially for one that used 12 starters.

4. Hamels time: Cole Hamels, 32, was acquired at midseason from the Philadelphia Phillies and will assume the No.1 spot in the rotation. He went 7-1 with a 3.66 ERA with the Rangers in 2015. The trade for the three-time All-Star helped the Rangers rally from an eight-game deficit in the division Aug. 2. This time the Rangers get a full season with Hamels.

Scott Boeck

Rangers' Yu Darvish anxious to return, take next step in rehab process

***

Toronto Blue Jays



1. Pitching: The Blue Jays have one of the most potent lineups in baseball, but after losing David Price they have a huge hole in their rotation. They will rely on budding star Marcus Stroman to be the ace, but he’s unproven. He has one full year in the majors after being out most of last year with a torn anterior cruciate ligament. In that one season, Stroman had good numbers, going 11-6 in 1302/3 innings and striking out 111, but not ace-caliber numbers. The combination of aging R.A. Dickey and boom-or-bust Marco Estrada doesn’t elicit fear in opposing batters. If the Blue Jays want to win, they’ll need Stroman to lead an aging rotation.

2. Health of stars: Jose Bautista and Edwin Encarnacion will be 35 and 33, respectively. Bautista has a history of injuries (wrist and hip), and Encarnacion missed time with an injury in 2014. The Blue Jays have begun discussing extensions with both sluggers, but 2016 will be a defining year. Both need to stay healthy to make sure the Blue Jays’ strength, their power, stays around.

3. Win on the road: The Blue Jays were lights out at home last season, going 53-28. On the road they played like a .500 team. Away from Rogers Centre their team ERA skyrocketed from 3.22 to 4.41. Dickey was 9-3 at home while striking out 74, but he went 2-8 on the road, where opponents hit .296 against him. If they want to win the AL East, the Jays need to be able to beat teams on the road with more consistent pitching.

4. Success against AL East: The Blue Jays are in arguably the AL’s best division. Last season Toronto won by going 42-34 against the division, including 13-6 vs. the second-place Yankees, who have a chance to threaten Toronto for the top spot this season.

Michael Stern

Troy Tulowitzki still seething over Rockie exit from Denver

search_result.title: Road to Stanleytown: Mighty sweet victory in Game 3 puts 1997 Red ...
search_result.text:
Gene Myers

Special to Detroit Free Press

In the spring of 1997 — a quarter-century ago — the Detroit Red Wings embarked on their quest to end a 42-year Stanley Cup drought.

The Free Press has commemorated that historic quest with a new book: “Stanleytown: The Inside Story of How the Stanley Cup Returned to the Motor City After 41 Frustrating Seasons.”

Day 21: May 6, 1997

The backstory: Gordie, we’re not in Hockeytown anymore! The Western Conference semifinals shifted to Southern California for Game 3 and that meant 10:30 p.m. face-offs, warrior princesses and new heroes. Could the Red Wings put a three-games-to-none stranglehold on the Mighty Ducks? Could a Wings-Ducks game consist of only 60 minutes? Could Slava Kozlov and Doug Brown continue lighting the lamp? All three answers turned out to be yes — but the next morning’s water cooler conversation and sports-talk radio focused just as much on a wardrobe malfunction years before the term gained popularity and long before the explosion of social media.

[ Red Wings face roster decisions: Debating who stays and who goes in 2022 ]

Follow every game: Live NHL Scores

Game 3: With their beaks against the wall, the Ducks built a two-goal lead in the first period — the first two-goal lead in the series — and for a switch, the Wings were the ones wailing about the officiating. The Ducks’ mostly quiet superstars — Paul Kariya at 11:19 and Teemu Selanne at 12:09 — scored 5-on-3 power-play goals. It all started at 9:34, when Vladimir Konstantinov committed an obvious tripping penalty. No problem there. But 62 seconds later, referee Bill McCreary slapped goalie Mike Vernon with a high-sticking penalty. Vernon skated to the ref, chewed him out and received a 10-minute misconduct. Kariya scored soon after on a one-timer from an impossible angle over Vernon’s stick-side shoulder. On the ensuing face-off, Nicklas Lidstrom raised his gloves and stick high on Selanne as he cruised along the boards. The Wings bench went nuts when Lidstrom was hit with a high-sticking penalty with 1:02 left on Vernon’s minor. Coach Scotty Bowman motioned that Selanne took a dive. Soon after, Kariya fed Selanne for a 2-0 lead, and the frenzied fans at the Pond quacked up. The night’s dramatics were only getting started. Kozlov, whose goal ended Game 2 in the third overtime, scored on a power play at 15:47. He won a battle along the boards, got off a shot, collected the rebound and fired it high past Mikhail Shtalenkov. In the second period, Ted Drury, after missing Game 2 with a nerve injury, restored the Ducks’ two-goal lead. But with the fans chanting “USA! USA!” as the Russians swarmed during a power play, Kozlov blasted a shot off a Duck and Igor Larionov poked the carom home. At 16:28, Brown tied it at 3 by scoring in his second straight game. The Wings outshot the Ducks, 23-6, in the period. And the onslaught continued in the final period. Sergei Fedorov got behind defenseman Dan Trebil, one of the rookie’s several costly mistakes, and beat Shtalenkov at 3:34. About 20 seconds later, Fedorov hit Kozlov with a pass, and he finished off a 90-foot breakaway with a backhand move. It was Kozlov’s fifth goal in his last five games. The Wings had their first two-goal lead and before long a three-game lead.

Worth noting: Free Press headline: Mighty sweet. … Kozlov (two goals, one assist), Fedorov (one goal, two assists) and Konstantinov (three assists) posted three-point nights. … “I’m so happy for Kozzie,” Larionov said, “because he was struggling all season long. He was kind of in the doghouse, but lately he has played the best hockey I’ve ever seen him play in Detroit. It’s hard for a young guy sometimes. I just told him this is the time to play the great hockey he can play.” … Bowman started with a new superstar line: Brendan Shanahan-Fedorov-Steve Yzerman. But a few shifts later the Russian Five were back together. … Grinder Joe Kocur didn’t play after he lost an edge early in the first period and crashed back-first into the boards. … Brown, 32, played only 49 regular-season games and none in the first round against St. Louis. His world changed against the Ducks. During a break in the series, he even caught a foul ball at Dodger Stadium. “You just keep waiting for your chance,” Brown said. “You have to keep believing in yourself and working hard. You try to practice and show the coaches what you can do and hope your number is called. It’s awful sitting out.”

GAME 2:Slava Kozlov ends classic marathon in 3OT

GAME 1:Surprise hero lifts Wings over Ducks in OT

Off the ice: Years before Janet Jackson’s “wardrobe malfunction” at the Super Bowl, the Stanley Cup playoffs endured its version before Game 3. New Zealand actress Lucy Lawless, star of the syndicated “Xena: Warrior Princess” television show, wore a revealing costume with an Uncle Sam motif to sing the national anthem. This was how Steve Schrader reported the aftermath in the Free Press: “How revealing? As she hit the final notes of the anthem, Lawless threw open her blue blazer and, well, spilled out of the top of her strapless red costume for all of the television audience to see. The next day, Lawless pleaded ignorance during an interview with Dick Purtan on WOMC-FM (104.3). ‘You mean I’ve been flashing on national TV?’ she said. “I am horrified. It did not really come down, did it? Only a little popped out? Big deal.’ When Purtan’s crew described the incident in detail for her, Lawless said, ‘Oh, you lie. … I don’t need that kind of publicity. I get plenty of attention as it is. That costume was too damn small. My mother will cry.”

Famous last words: Ducks coach Ron Wilson remained irked that the Wings fired his father, Larry, and an uncle, Johnny, as coaches back in the day. Wilson pointed out he was born one month after the Wings won their last Stanley Cup in 1955. (Johnny was a left wing on that team, but he was dealt with Tony Leswick, Glen Skov and Benny Woit to Chicago after the season, a trade that produced almost nothing for the Wings.) “They haven’t won a Cup since I was born,” Wilson said. “Maybe that has something to do with it. Maybe that’s an omen. We just want to make sure it keeps going.”

Relive the glory: The Free Press has crafted a 208-page, full-color, hardcover collector’s book with fresh insights and dynamic storytelling about the 1996-97 Wings. It’s called “Stanleytown 25 Years Later: The Inside Story on How the Stanley Cup Returned to the Motor City after 41 Frustrating Seasons.” It’s only $29.95 and it’s available at RedWings.PictorialBook.com. (It’ll make a great Mother’s Day or Father’s Day gift for the Wings fanatic in your life!) Personalized copies available via myersgene@comcast.net.

[ Want more Wings news? Download our free mobile app on iPhone or Android! ]

More to read: Another new Wings book arrived in April from Keith Gave, a longtime hockey writer for the Free Press in the 1980s and 1990s: “Vlad The Impaler: More Epic Tales from Detroit’s ’97 Stanley Cup Conquest.” It is available through Amazon and other booksellers and a portion of the proceeds is earmarked for the Vladimir Konstantinov Special Needs Trust. (Plenty of Gave’s prose also appears in “Stanleytown 25 Years Later.”)

Even more to read: Red Wings beat reporter Helene St. James, who helped cover the 1997 Stanley Cup run, recently wrote “The Big 50: The Men and Moments That Made the Detroit Red Wings.” Featuring numerous tales about the key figures from 1997, “The Big 50” is available from Amazon, Barnes & Noble and Triumph Books. (Plenty of St. James’ prose also appears in “Stanleytown 25 Years Later.”)

search_result.text:
The Los Angeles Dodgers ended their 32-year dry spell without a World Series championship Tuesday night -- and the Dodgers' faithful can finally celebrate after winning eight consecutive NL West titles, yet falling short in the Fall Classic in back-to-back seasons (2017 and 2018).

The Dodgers' title drought wasn't as long as the team that won the World Series a year ago (the Washington Nationals had never won in the franchise's 51-year history, which included its time as the Montreal Expos) ... or the team that prevailed in 2016 (the Chicago Cubs' previous championship came 108 years earlier, in 1908). However, it does get them off the list of MLB teams with the most frustrated fan bases.

WORLD SERIES:Rays manager Kevin Cash's decision to pull Blake Snell proves costly in Game 6 loss

A BLACK EYE:Season of sacrifice for MLB ends with galling breach of protocol

Here then, is our ranking of the clubs best poised to end their own lengthy stints without winning a World Series.

1. San Diego Padres (52 years, 0 titles)

The Padres made the playoffs in 2020 for the first time in 14 years, but the nucleus of their 37-23 team looks poised to help them contend for several years to come. SS Fernando Tatis Jr. is already a superstar and his double-play partner, 2B Jake Cronenworth, has a good chance at winning NL Rookie of the Year honors. From established stars Manny Machado and Eric Hosmer to one of MLB's top farm systems, the future is bright.

On the pitching side, the midseason acquisition of Mike Clevinger gives them a legitimate ace to go along with Dinelson Lamet and Chris Paddack, with top prospects MacKenzie Gore, Luis Patiño, Ryan Weathers and Adrian Morejon waiting in the wings.

Prediction: Next title in 2022

2. Seattle Mariners (44 years, 0 titles)

Perhaps the most disappointing fact for Mariners fans is that they had ace Felix Hernandez for 15 seasons and never once made the playoffs. Current GM Jerry DiPoto is known for his unending appetite for making trades (and never really making much progress), but it does look like there's a pretty solid foundation at long last.

Of their key players, only 3B Kyle Seager is over 30. Young infielders J.P. Crawford and Evan White are AL Gold Glove finalists. CF Kyle Lewis is the favorite for AL Rookie of the Year. And in the minors, the M's have two of the game's top-five overall prospects in OFs Julio Rodriguez, 19, and Jarred Kelenic, 21 -- who should both be ready to contribute next season. Pitching, however, remains an issue.

Prediction: Next title in 2027

3. Cleveland Indians (72 years since last title in 1948)

The Indians came oh-so-close to winning it all in 2016, needing only a victory in Game 6 or 7 at home to close out the Cubs. With a young core and outstanding pitching, it looked like they'd be back fairly soon. Even though top starters Corey Kluber, Trevor Bauer and Clevinger are no longer in Cleveland, Shane Bieber has emerged as the team's ace of the future.

The big question for the Indians is what happens to All-Star shortstop Francisco Lindor, who becomes a free agent after the 2021 season. Will they trade him and start rebuilding? Or will they make one last push for a championship?

Prediction: Next title in 2030

4. New York Mets (34 years since last title in 1986)

The Mets are seemingly close to getting a new ownership group in place. That change could make a greater impact than anything they might be able to do on the field for the next few years.

1B Pete Alonso, OF Michael Conforto and SS Amed Rosario are solid building blocks, but the Mets may have missed the window to challenge for a title while Jacob deGrom and Noah Syndergaard are at the height of their powers. The farm system doesn't look like it's going to be much help for a while.

Prediction: Next title in 2035

5. Detroit Tigers (36 years since last title in 1984)

The Tigers had quite a run under manager Jim Leyland, especially from 2011-13 when they reached the ALCS all three years and won it once. But a lack of reliable relief pitching always seemed to be the Achilles heel that kept the Tigers from winning it all.

Former AL MVP Miguel Cabrera powered the Tigers offense during those good times, but he's now a shell of his former self as the team has begun rebuilding. Cabrera is still under contract through at least 2023 -- so it might take a while to get everything back on track. When they do, it will likely be on the strength of a talented core of young starting pitchers: Casey Mize, Matt Manning, Tarik Skubal and Beau Burrows.

Prediction: Next title in 2037

6. Milwaukee Brewers (52 years, no titles)

The Brewers have made the postseason for three consecutive years, a first in franchise history. But a closer look at where they've finished in the NL Central during those years -- first, second, fourth -- reveals a disturbing trend.

They broke the bank for MVP Christian Yelich, signing him through 2028, so the challenge will be finding ways to build around him. We've already seen how difficult that's been for the Los Angeles Angels and their superstar, Mike Trout. 2B Keston Hiura and RPs Josh Hader and Devin Williams have yet to turn 27, but Milwaukee will need a greater infusion of young talent to get Yelich that title.

Prediction: Next title in 2039

7. Texas Rangers (60 years, no titles)

The Rangers lost back-to-back World Series in 2010-11 and haven't won a playoff series since. In 2020, they moved into a brand-new stadium and finished with the worst record in the American League.

The old open-air Globe Life Park was hitter-friendly. The new retractable-roof Globe Life Field seemed to favor the pitchers. There's a metaphor in there somewhere. Until the Rangers figure out their identity, they're likely stuck in the middle.

Prediction: Next title in 2045

8. Pittsburgh Pirates (41 years since last title in 1979)

No team's fanbase has been tortured more than the Pirates'. And it's not even close. There was a brief blip of contention from 2013-15 when they made the postseason (however briefly), but for the most part it's been continuous suffering ever since young Barry Bonds left town in 1992.

The Tyler Glasnow/Austin Meadows-for-Chris Archer trade sent the franchise into a downward spiral and will continue to haunt the Pirates for years. Maybe decades. There's no loaded farm system like the Padres and Mariners have. There's no former MVP to build around. There's no new ownership group waiting in the wings. But at least there's a gorgeous ballpark.

Prediction: Next title in 2060

search_result.text:
NOTE: This story was updated on Jan. 18, 2022, to make it free for all readers.

And then what happened?

It's a popular internet jest today, attached to highlight video clips or celebration of a small success that was followed by a bigger letdown. The Bucks win a game by 25, but a basketball Twitter account is fawning over a violent dunk by an opposing player? Fine. "And then what happened?"

Fifty years after the Milwaukee Bucks won the 1971 NBA title, sports fans in Milwaukee have been facing some variation of that question ever since. Heck, Milwaukee sports teams have only been in the championship round of major pro sports twice since the Bucks crushed the Baltimore Bullets, 4-0, for the championship, and one of those was back in 1974.

It's been a half-century of quiet. We're cursed or something, right?

Follow every game: Live NBA Scores

If we're talking all major pro sports and considering only championships, Milwaukee's length of wait is behind only San Diego and Buffalo, whose last titles came with the 1963 and 1965 AFL championships.

Sacramento hasn't won a crown in men's major sports since the Kings arrived in 1985, although the Sacramento Monarchs won the WNBA title in 2005.

Charlotte hasn't had a title since pro sports arrived with the Hornets in 1988. That's likewise true for Orlando, which hasn't won a title since the Magic joined the NBA in 1989.

In MLB, only one older franchise (Texas Rangers, founded in 1961) has yet to win a World Series, and only two (Cleveland, last winning in 1948) have faced a longer overall drought than the Brewers.

In the NBA, five franchises have faced longer droughts than Milwaukee's 49-year wait: Sacramento (69 years, dating to its days in Rochester), Atlanta (62), Phoenix (never in 52 years) and the Los Angeles Clippers (never in 50 years).

For those unfamiliar, here is our story of woe.

OK, we probably should acknowledge the Packers first

We're probably not fooling anyone when we complain about lack of sports success. Sure, the Green Bay Packers play two hours to the north (unless it's a Gold Package game day, then it's a lot more than two hours), but they represent one of the most recognizable and successful franchises in pro sports, and Milwaukeeans love the Packers.

While Packers fans have gotten antsy that the haul isn't more substantial, Green Bay has hoisted four Lombardi trophies, and two since that 1971 Bucks title. The franchise has made nine NFC championship games since 1995 alone, with so many divisional titles in that stretch (14) that it barely registers to anyone when it happens.

In 1970, the Milwaukee Brewers arrived in town, mending some of the wound left behind when the Milwaukee Braves left town after 1965. The Braves won the 1957 World Series title and didn't endure a losing season in 13 years. Surely, the Brewers would ascend to those heights at some point, right?

At the same time, the Bucks had one of the biggest names in pro basketball (Lew Alcindor then, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar shortly thereafter), and he didn't even turn 24 years old until late in the championship season. Surely this was just the start of something special. Bob Dandridge and Lucius Allen were 23, Greg Smith and Dick Cunningham 24, Jon McGlocklin 27. Sure, Oscar Robertson was 32, but he wasn't slowing down.

The question wasn't when the Bucks would win another championship. It was how many.

The encore years go wrong for the Bucks

The Bucks still won 63 games in 1971-72 but couldn't get past the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference finals. Jerry West was hurt in 1971 when the teams met in the same spot; he wasn't this time, and Jim McMillian had blossomed into a major contributor.

In 1972-73, Milwaukee won 60 games and was absolutely stunned by the 47-35 Golden State Warriors in the conference semifinals. Maybe Milwaukee would win only two or three titles instead of, like, eight?

Milwaukee got back to the NBA finals in 1974, going 8-1 against the Lakers and Bulls heading into the finals against Boston. Abdul-Jabbar hit a famous skyhook to beat the Celtics at the Boston Garden in double overtime of Game 6. But when the series shifted back to Milwaukee, Boston toppled the Bucks, 102-87.

Robertson wound up retiring.

Speaking of wounds that took a long time to heal, Abdul-Jabbar asked to leave town shortly before the 1975 season, believing he and the Milwaukee environment weren't compatible. We had just started Summerfest, too, and the Domes had been completed if you like, you know, plants.

The deal got completed after the year to send him to the Lakers, where Abdul-Jabbar won five more NBA championships and set a record for career scoring that still hasn't been broken. The Bucks haven't been back to the finals since.

Meanwhile, the summers weren't much better

The Bucks got a solid return in the Abdul-Jabbar deal but mostly became a sub-.500 team in the short term.

At least they tasted championship-caliber play. The Brewers still weren't close during their first eight seasons in town. But then came 1978. General manager Harry Dalton took the reins and acquired MVP candidate Larry Hisle. Mike Caldwell was a Cy Young candidate. Manager George Bamberger and "Bambi's Bombers" became a thing.

The Brewers won 93 games in 1978 and 95 in 1979. Those are playoff-caliber numbers today, but at that point, you basically had to win 100 to get to the ALCS. They finished 6½ games out — in third place — in 1978. Eight games out in 1979. A full 17 out in 1980 despite a quality 86-win season. A breakthrough was coming, but it was hard-earned.

Meanwhile, the Bucks clawed their way back to relevance. In the first full year under coach/scientist Don Nelson, the "Green and Growing Bucks" reached the conference semifinals, kicking off a 10-year run in which the Bucks reached the conference semis or finals nine times. Nellieball had arrived!

Marques Johnson, Sidney Moncrief, Junior Bridgeman, Bob Lanier, Brian Winters, Mickey Johnson and Quinn Buckner all on the same team!

But Milwaukee simply couldn't break through. Philadelphia — a recurring annoyance — won Game 7 of the 1981 Eastern Conference semifinals, 99-98, and brought a 60-win Milwaukee season to an end. Philly got Milwaukee again in 1982 and 1983 before Boston got honors in the 1984 conference finals. The Bucks won 59 games in 1984-85, but the 76ers rudely swept Milwaukee away in the conference semis.

Oh, and Michael Jordan showed up. Milwaukee may have gotten past him as a rookie in the 1985 playoffs (that was our favorite part of "The Last Dance"), but the Eastern Conference was eventually going to belong to our southern neighbors.

The closest call for a Milwaukee title since Kareem

The Brewers' breakthrough came in the second half of a strike-shortened 1981 season. Rollie Fingers was MVP and Cy Young, although the Yankees got the best of the Brewers in the divisional series format, 3-2.

Still: Cecil Cooper, Robin Yount, Ted Simmons, Ben Oglivie, Jim Gantner, Gorman Thomas, Paul Molitor, Caldwell and Pete Vuckovich all on the same team!

Harvey Kuenn took over as Brewers manager early in the 1982 season and Harvey's Wallbangers got to work, winning 95 games and holding off the Orioles on the last day of the regular season to win the American League East.

But in September, Fingers was injured and missed the rest of the year.

They defeated the Angels anyway in a thrilling five-game AL Championship Series. Milwaukee was headed to its first World Series, then took a 3-2 lead in the final showdown with the Cardinals.

The Brewers needed to win only one more game in St. Louis to bring the title home. But the Cardinals won Game 6, 13-1, and Game 7, 6-3. The Brewers got a parade anyway, which is more than you can say for the Bucks in 1971.

But the Brewers haven't been back to the World Series since.

At least the Bucks finally dismissed the 76ers in a seven-game Eastern Conference semis in 1986, and then again in the 1987 first round, 3-2. Too bad the otherworldly Celtics were waiting both times.

By 1988, Milwaukee had a new arena for the Bucks, but Don Nelson was gone. "I feel that I am the Milwaukee Bucks," he said during a 1987 interview with the New York Daily News, and that didn't sit well with owner Herb Kohl. Nelson resigned, and Del Harris took over.

The Bucks lost in the Eastern Conference semis in 1989, then didn't win another playoff series until 2001. For seven seasons from 1991-1998, Milwaukee didn't reach the playoffs at all.

The '90s weren't great on the diamond, either

The Brewers' tour through the mid-to-late 1980s included several unremarkable seasons and one crazy "Team Streak" campaign in 1987, which featured a no-hitter, a legendary winning streak to start the year, Paul Molitor's hitting streak and Teddy Higuera dominating. It still wasn't a playoff year.

In 1992, Milwaukee briefly snapped back to life with a 92-win season but finished four games out of the playoffs. The next 12 Brewers seasons were sub-.500, and Milwaukee couldn't take advantage of an expanded MLB playoff system adopted in 1994.

The construction of a new stadium with a retractable roof was marred by a tragic crane collapse that killed three workers and delayed the opening of Miller Park a year, to 2001.

New home in 2001, but same struggles

The new stadium's opening, coupled with a pretty fun Bucks team in 2001, briefly gave Milwaukee its sports buzz again. The Bucks, led by coach George Karl and the "big three" of Ray Allen, Glenn Robinson and Sam Cassell, finally won the franchise's first playoff series since 1989, then won a seven-game thriller over Charlotte to get into the finals against ... aw, man, it's Philadelphia again.

The series went seven games and ended with a controversial suspension and notable foul disparity. Philadelphia and star point guard Allen Iverson won the seventh game.

The Bucks were on the cusp of another 17 years without a playoff series win, including eight first-round exits. In that stretch, Milwaukee did occasionally get high lottery picks, but players such as Andrew Bogut (No. 1 in 2005), Yi Jianlian (No. 6 in 2007), Joe Alexander (No. 8 in 2008), Brandon Jennings (No. 10 in 2009), Jabari Parker (No. 2 in 2014) and Thon Maker (No. 10 in 2016) never achieved superstar status, or in most cases, anything resembling it. Bogut became a rock-solid contributor for seven seasons and borderline all-star, but injuries derailed his career.

The Bucks were treading water. At least they drafted this teenager from Greece in 2013 with a very hard-to-pronounce last name. He might turn out.

The Brewers are back, baby!

In 2008, the Brewers were finally back in the playoffs after a 26-year drought. With the midseason acquisition of CC Sabathia and the 1-2 punch of Prince Fielder and Ryan Braun in the lineup, the Brewers were good enough to get back into the playoffs. A dramatic win over the Cubs on the final day of the season gave the Brewers 90 wins and a wild-card berth.

The playoffs themselves ... ugh. Can we please be done with Philadelphia?

The Brewers weren't done there, though. In 2011, Milwaukee won the division for the first time since 1982, then won a heart-stopping fifth game of the divisional series over Arizona. The Brewers were so close to the World Series! But St. Louis, the team that toppled Milwaukee's dream in 1982, interrupted the ride again with a six-game win in the NLCS.

Finally, both are good at the same time

In 2018, both the Bucks and Brewers had MVPs on their roster.

The Brewers acquired Christian Yelich before the 2018 season, and all he did was win the National League MVP award and help the Brewers win another division title (defeating the Cubs in Game 163) and an NLCS berth (that again ended in heartbreak, a seven game loss to the Dodgers).

Giannis Antetokounmpo blossomed into a superstar for the Bucks. He was a force by 2018, even though the Bucks lost in seven games to the Celtics in the opening round of the playoffs. Under new coach Mike Budenholzer and in the new Fiserv Forum in 2018-19, the team won 60 games. Giannis won MVP, the Bucks won their first two playoff series and then took a 2-0 lead on Toronto in the Eastern Conference Finals. That's where another fun ride ended.

Toronto won the series (and the subsequent championship). Though Giannis was an MVP again the following year and the Bucks again had the best record in the league, Milwaukee couldn't get out of the Eastern Conference semifinals against Miami.

The team appears willing to sacrifice regular-season success for postseason preparation in 2020-21, and Giannis has signed to stay in Milwaukee (meaning he wasn't going to follow in Abdul-Jabbar's footsteps). But Milwaukee remains on the lookout for its first finals trip since 1974.

Yelich, who finished second in the MVP voting in 2019, was injured late in the season and missed the wild-card game, a gut-wrenching loss to eventual World Series champion Washington that featured an eighth-inning collapse.

But he, too, signed to stay long term in Milwaukee before the 2020 season, which was marred by a pandemic, a dramatically shortened schedule and overall offensive struggles for the Brewers, even though they did manage a playoff spot with a losing record.

Plus, Milwaukee has still had its triumphs.

The Milwaukee Wave indoor soccer team won its first league championship in 1998 and has racked up six more since, including the 2019 crown.

The Milwaukee Admirals hockey team won the 2004 Calder Cup and the USHL title in 1976.

Heck, even in 2020, the Milwaukee Milkmen independent baseball team won the championship in the fledgling American Association of Professional Baseball.

Moreover, while the Brewers' offensive struggles have continued into the earliest days of the 2021 season, they're still off to a good start as they seek to continue an unprecedented run of postseason appearances. Perhaps this is also, in fact, the Bucks' year to break through.

We'll see what happens.

JR Radcliffe can be reached at (262) 361-9141 or jradcliffe@gannett.com. Follow him on Twitter at @JRRadcliffe.
